newsitem.title: JAPAN: Analysts say interests match in Sega, Bandai merger.
newsitem.headline: Analysts say interests match in Sega, Bandai merger.

text.p: A mutual interest of survival in the increasingly competitive video game market brought gamemaker Sega Enterprises Ltd and toy manufacturer Bandai Co Ltd together, analysts said on Thursday.
"With the decreasing number of children and limited possible growth in the toy industry, Bandai is entering the game industry," said Masahiro Ono, analyst at Credit Lyonnaise Securities (Japan).
"Sega, meanwhile, seems interested in the toy industry. It has planning ability, but lacks a way of circulating products," Ono said.
"Bandai needs Sega's ability and know-how in the digital field, while Sega wants Bandai's characters to support its game contents. So each side's demands meet," he added.

The two companies announced they were merging to form a new company, Sega-Bandai, effective October 1. In the deal, each Bandai share will be exchanged for 0.76 Sega shares, and Bandai will be dissolved after the transaction is completed.
But some analysts said that they could not see what the deal would accomplish.
"It is hard to see a merit in the merger," said Yasuo Imanaka, analyst at the Okasan Economic Research Institute.
"Both companies have problems in similar fields," he said, adding that Sega would have to find a way to gain ground that it has lost in the "Sega Saturn" game.

In December, Sega said that it had lowered its earnings forecast for the year to March 31, 1997, because it would get rid of its inventory of products related to its 16-bit machines and erase accumulated losses at its U.S. unit.
Sega also said in December that it would dispose of 16-bit machine-related products, worth about seven billion yen worldwide.
"I don't think the (new) firm can beat Sony's PlayStation in any way," Imanaka said.
"I'll wait and see how they (both firms) are going to get along with the problems after October 1," he said.
Yutaka Sugiyama, analyst at UBS Securities Ltd, also said that the purpose of the merger was unclear.
"I don't understand the aim of the merger, but it would be easier for them to adjust their strategies," he said.
Analysts also pointed out the difference in the two firms' corporate cultures.
"The focus is how they cooperate with each other to unify their management policies," said Yasuaki Fujine, analyst at Smith Barney.
Both firms have faced recent financial problems.
In December, Sega lowered its forecast for a net profit for 1996/97 by almost half to 5.3 billion yen from a November forecast of 10 billion yen, against its 1995/96 profit of 4.21 billion yen.

Bandai said earlier this month that it would post group net loss of nine billion yen in the year to March 31, 1997, against its previous forecast of a net profit of 10.50 billion yen. It posted a group net profit of 10.36 billion yen in 1995/96.
